description: A person associated with the Houston Astros was said to be removed by security during Game 1 at Fenway Park after seemingly taking photos of the Boston dugout.
title: M.L.B. Clears Astros of Wrongdoing in Investigation of Surveillance of Red Sox Dugout
title_page: M.L.B. Clears Astros of Wrongdoing in Investigation of Surveillance of Red Sox Dugout - The New York Times
maintext:
HOUSTON — Major League Baseball announced on Wednesday that it had concluded its investigation into an incident at Fenway Park during Game 1 of the American League Championship Series on Saturday in which an employee of the Houston Astros was removed by security after apparently taking photographs of the Red Sox’ dugout.
The man was removed from the area early in the game, which the Astros won, 7-2.
The league concluded that the person was not attempting to steal signs or other proprietary information, but rather he “was monitoring the field to ensure that the opposing club was not violating any rules.”
Astros General Manager Jeff Luhnow acknowledged the Astros have engaged in this practice for some time to prevent other teams from stealing their signs. But he called it a defensive program, not an offensive one.
“As a matter of course when we go into an opposing stadium, an in our home stadium, we look around to make sure there’s nothing suspicious going on,” Luhnow said. “We do it in every stadium we go into. We’re going to continue to have our eyes open.”
